page.title: 18LOCAL HISTORY IN WELSHPOOL
page.content: {The Welshpool Cockpit}stands off New Street behind the National Westminster Bank which was once the site of the Castle Inn. The site of the cockpit was known as Bloody Field, the scene of a fatal duel over a cockfight. The cockpit, which is assumed to have been built in the eighteenth century, is hexagonal in plan and built of brick with a slate roof. Usually the ordinary people stood around the cockpit on the cobbled yard floor whilst the more important stood in the gallery above. However in Welshpool this is not the case as the pit was on the upper floor. The building was officially used as a cockpit until the sport was made illegal in 1849. It has now been fully restored to its original condition.
